comments.commentBody: The difference is: Shia was always always always a joke; there was a time when Johnny was not.

Sorry ... I had some of the football players in my classes at PSU and there was no pass-through at all. All their work was well done and they deserved the "A" grades they earned.
Money is not the way to measure a career.
Tell that to Eli Manning...

Brady himself brought the court case, and his lawyers could have applied for a protective order regarding the other matters on the phone. Or his own lawyers probably could have just reviewed the information on his phone and only turned over material that was relevant to the proceedings.

But destruction of potentially pertinent information, in a court case that he himself brought, and under circumstances that suggest it was deliberate? Apart from possibly being illegal (e.g., if intentional), it is something courts will hold against you, and rightfully so.

No, it has nothing to do with the Seahawks - the Birds managed to lose that all on their own.  This is about an organization with a culture of cheating - that only wins by cheating.  Let's be honest - cheating shouldn't pay - and that's what this decision is about.

Except there is evidence that he knowingly cheated.  Only PATS fans ignore that somewhat apparently inconvenient fact.  The fact that the Patriots have been caught cheating before didn't help their case either.  Winning shouldn't trump fair play.
With conclusive facts and incontrovertible evidence in his favor, one would have thought that Brady would have won his court case instead of losing it.

Transforming pain, personal and collective, Beyonce combines music, spoken word, and storytelling into something that I would not hesitate to call art that is emotionally, culturally and politically powerful.

Though sourced from something intensely personal -- raw betrayal of a cheating spouse, namely her own (she calls out Jay-Z in no uncertain terms) -- she expands her point of view to embrace universal strengths, which she clearly believes, for her, is rooted in the stories, resilience, tribulations and triumphs of Black womanhood.

Diverse musical influences (soul, rap, rock, country), poetry by Somali-British poet Warsan Shire, and captivating imagery conspire to convey an emotional journey from rage to reconciliation, from despair to hope, from destruction to resurrection.

Unafraid, Beyonce ventures to posit, mostly via some hauntingly poignant film sequences, that these same emotions inform human interactions based on race and gender. She is bold here in ways she has not been before.

Watching this, I cried. I dropped jaw at the raw honesty displayed. And, I was moved by the possibilities of healing despite the rage. I loved it. It's an hour long but worth the time.

now I know why her sister lapped the silly out of JayZ and Beyonce didn't do anything about it in the elevator in that incident a couple years ago.  But for all you poo pooing her star power, get real.  She is terrific.
Actually, you could see very clearly where the horde was circling around her. He was looking in about a 10 foot circle...
Yes, and the melancholic way she looked, it may cost her a great deal.
If that's true then I'm done.

There seems to be a universal consensus amongst all thrones fans and nerds that Jon is alive.

However, they killed Prince Doran, who was the focal point of many of the best fan theories I've read about bringing down the Lannisters and getting the upper hand in Westeros (Dornish Master Plan video on YouTube). Killing him is a huge curveball and that can't be underappreciated.

That said, I think the books and the show are now going to tell two very different stories, and that this season is the major point of departure. It would completely unseat all fan theories and expectations if they actually killed Jon, and that is very much in the style of the show. I'm saying that BECAUSE the writers and GRRM know that everyone wants (knows?) Jon is coming back, they might have written that narrative completely out of the season to surprise us.

So what if Jon is actually dead?
Podrick, not Gendry.

"It seems like rational people ought to be able to decide what's in their own good;"

I was wondering why people smoke. Now I know. It's rational.
@ Pierce Randall, the health problems caused by an individual's decision to consume soft drinks impose costs not only on the individual but on all of us.

Then we need to tax people who ski or skydive. We also need to tax people who have sex with too many partners. Where does it all end? Micro managing citizens personal behavior is a limit most Americans don't want crossed. We will all just need to live with the "cost" of most health risks that we all take with our individual lives each day. You're not going to succeed into micro managing individual behavior to some imaginary point of perfection.

Either the objective for the tax is revenue or the objective is behavioral change (or both).

It's fair to criticize the tax on revenue grounds because it's regressive. Krugman suggests that we should see the tax-as-revenue issue as linked with the policy that it funds. But I don't see why that's the case. Pre-K in Philadelphia could be funded a lot of different ways. Some of those ways are less regressive than a soda tax. So it seems like the regressivity of the tax understood as a way to pay for something is a separate issue from the progressivity of what it's supposed to pay for.

I'm not sure what to think of the tax as a way to change behavior. Normally, we don't think that restricting someone's option set, either by raising the cost of some options or by preventing them outright, is justified if it's done solely on the basis of the good of the person being so restricted. It seems like rational people ought to be able to decide what's in their own good; it's not clear why the state should take money from them up to the point that the better angels of their natures kick in. But then the issue is more complicated because it involves family purchases that may affect children. I'm not sure if that's a sufficient justification for a paternalistic tax or not. Probably, it's not something easy to work out without looking at numbers: how much benefit are we likely to receive and what are the burdens it will place on people who pay the tax?

It seems it is also being done to stop the shooting and killing of mentally ill persons. Attempts to deescalate and disable using nonviolence or nonlethal means first is the focus of the training.
Indeed there is so much to be done in the treatment area.
This initiative by Portland is good news and a good start.

Wow! I hadn't seen your post, and I said exactly what you said, almost word for word!

Amen!

It would be nice if people commenting here would do a little research.  "President" Reagan didn't undertake the deinstitutionalization of the mentally ill as a policy choice; neither did he as Governor.  This is the ACLU's idea; they sued to dismantle the organized mental health system.  Now, you cannot force a mentally ill person to undergo treatment or take medication, use a shelter or stop harassing the public.
Michael Brown?  You're kidding, right?  Ignore a strong arm robbery?  Just let the thief and assailant wander away?  Sounds lovely.
Only one problem with your analysis--you cannot make a mentally ill person take  his meds or go to therapy.  None of the people being described in these incidents are willing to seek medical help.

I thought Dena Blizzard was hilarious and hits the nail on the head about what it's like to be a parent these days. As a working mom, I could totally relate and I need the belly laughs that night! She is great and not to be missed!
Sorry Neil if you didn't understand the act...but for ANY mom in the audience, trust me, we can all relate! Fantastic show Ms. Blizzard. You're much more than a former Miss New Jersey - you're a mom trying to keep it all together in this crazy world we raise our kids in today!

"Was there a momentum to bring this play to Broadway?

Ego?...as in "TV star"....that's a trite answer since Jesse does do Shakespeare in the Park regularly (well, btw)...and I love him for it.

What is the "momentum" for any Broadway show?  To entertain, to bring people to the theatre.  (OK, to make money).  I'd say that this piece was revived because it seemed like a fun thing to do, with a star that would give it new life (i.e. "revival").  The script was updated and JTF's performance is pretty amazing.  Let's keep in mind that the $147 price noted in this strange review is the top dollar price -- you can come and see it for 1/3 of that if you like, and having sat in the cheap seats myself I can say that it was a perfectly wonderful evening in the theatre.  Jesse fills the stage wonderfully.

Was there a momentum to bring this play to Broadway? Were people calling out for a revival? No reason is given here for rescuscitating Fully Committed. At today's ticket prices, I find my calendar is also fully committed.
The house that's divided against itself is dividing against itself.  The GOP has turned into party of separate tribes.
I will not rest easy until Bernie Sanders is elected.

A simple question: Where have you and your fellow antiwar activists been for the past 7 1/2 years? Since the beginning of the Obama presidency? Many of us are wondering what is actually being protested; the wars or the Republicans?
People will vote in November, but I expect a low presidential tally.
